subject: Re: [junit] Junit4 with command line
msgSnippet: hyca, On some older JUnit4 checkins, if your test class extends TestCase, then it is run as a JUnit 3.x test case, even if it has JUnit4-style annotations.
messageBody:
hyca,

On some older JUnit4 checkins, if your test class extends TestCase, then
it is run as a JUnit 3.x test case, even if it has JUnit4-style
annotations. Removing "extends TestCase" should be all it takes. I
think that the most recent check-in will look for the suite() method
first, which would change this answer. Unfortunately, SourceForge CVS
is down, so I can't verify that right now.

Share and Enjoy,

David Saff

hyca51 wrote:

> Here is tests with the new version of Junit4
>
> import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import org.junit.Test;
>
> public class AdditionTest extends TestCase {
>
> private int x = 1;
> private int y = 1;
>
> @Test public void testAddition() {
> int z = x + y;
> assertEquals(2, z);
> }
>
> @Test public void countOne() {
> assertEquals(1, 1);
> }
>
> static public junit.framework.Test suite() {
> return new JUnit4TestAdapter(AdditionTest.class);
> }
>
> }
>
> Run on command line:
> java -classpath .;..\lib\junit4.jar org.junit.runner.JUnitCore
> AdditionTest
>
> Output:
> Core AdditionTest
> JUnit version 4.0rc1
> .
> Time: 0,015
>
> OK (1 test)
>
> As you've seen only the test testAddition is recognised and executed,
> the other test countOne could not be recognised.
>
> I tried to run within eclipse, both tests are recognised and executed.
> I've changed the countOne to testCountOne, then the test testCountOne
> works on the command line as well. What have I done wrong with the
> command line? Please help. Thanks in advance.
>
>
